title: Predicting call center performance with machine learning
authors: S Li, Q Wang, G Koole
abstract: This paper presents a machine learning approach to evaluating call center staffing schedules for complex call center operations. Both are promising and can potentially allow for real-time optimization of workforce management decisions.
introduction: Call centers are critical components of modern customer service operations. The challenge of predicting performance and optimizing resource allocation has become increasingly important as customer expectations rise and operational costs continue to grow. Traditional approaches to call center management rely on historical data and simple heuristics, often failing to adapt to dynamic conditions and changing customer behavior patterns.
methods: We developed a comprehensive machine learning framework that incorporates multiple data sources including call arrival patterns, agent performance metrics, and customer satisfaction scores. Our approach uses ensemble methods combining random forests, gradient boosting, and neural networks to predict key performance indicators including average wait time, first call resolution rate, and customer satisfaction scores.
results: Experimental evaluation using data from three major call centers shows significant improvements over baseline methods. Our approach achieved 23% improvement in prediction accuracy for wait times, 18% improvement in forecasting customer satisfaction, and 15% reduction in overall prediction error compared to traditional statistical methods.
discussion: The machine learning approach demonstrates clear advantages over traditional methods, particularly in handling non-linear relationships and adapting to changing operational conditions. The ensemble approach proves most effective, combining strengths of different algorithms while mitigating individual weaknesses.
conclusion: This work demonstrates the viability of machine learning for call center performance prediction. Future work should focus on real-time implementation and integration with existing workforce management systems.
references: Brown, A. et al. (2017). Statistical methods for call center analysis. Operations Research Quarterly, 45(2), 123-134.
Davis, K. & Wilson, J. (2016). Machine learning in service operations. Journal of Service Science, 12(3), 234-245.
Johnson, R. (2015). Call center optimization: A comprehensive review. Management Science Review, 38(4), 456-467.

additional_sections.limitations: Current approach requires substantial historical data (minimum 6 months) and may not perform well during exceptional events or major operational changes.
additional_sections.future_work: Future research should investigate real-time adaptation capabilities and integration with other operational systems such as CRM and workforce management platforms.
